title: 111_hr5694
content: The Act may be cited as the "One Global Internet Act of 2010". Congress finds that a single, open, global Internet is essential for the free flow of information and products across borders. Policies should encourage global technology standards, respect user privacy and security, protect intellectual property rights, and promote innovation without imposing restrictions on Internet service. Certain governments are adopting policies contrary to the goal of a single open, global Internet, including mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and requiring forfeiture of intellectual property in Internet-related technologies. Certain governments are adopting policies contrary to the goal of a single open, global Internet, including mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and requiring forfeiture of intellectual property in Internet-related technologies. This includes conditions of market access for commercial and civilian uses or government procurement, sponsoring unauthorized access to networks for disruption or intellectual property infringement, restricting Internet communications in a discriminatory manner, and imposing discriminatory market access requirements or liabilities. Actions that discriminate against or impede Internet-related goods, services, and content from other countries threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating foreign governments' attempts to restrict the free flow of information on the Internet, promoting conflicting "national Internets," harming US workers and businesses, and giving foreign competitors an advantage. Actions that discriminate against or impede Internet-related goods, services, and content from other countries threaten the utility of the Internet as a tool of open communication, assembly, and commerce, putting individuals at risk. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established to address actions that hinder international Internet goods and services, jeopardizing open communication and commerce. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established within the executive branch, consists of various government officials including the United States Trade Representative, Secretary of State, Chief Technology Officer, Secretary of Commerce, and others. The President selects a Chairperson from among the Task Force members. The Task Force on the Global Internet, comprised of government officials, can request assistance from other departments and agencies to address foreign government policies that hinder international trade in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force on the Global Internet aims to address barriers to international trade in Internet-related goods and services by coordinating executive branch departments, preparing strategies, and developing a report and action plan. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO CONGRESS. The Task Force will provide a report and action plan to Congress identifying foreign government acts that restrict trade in Internet-related goods and services or promote discriminatory technology standards. The Task Force will provide a report to Congress identifying foreign government acts that restrict trade in Internet-related goods and services, estimate their impact on US commerce and the Internet, designate priority concerns, and outline a strategy for executive branch response. The Task Force will submit annual reports detailing measures taken in response to identified restrictions on Internet-related trade by foreign governments, including any required actions under section 5. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary. Coordination with relevant government agencies, public participation, and consideration of various information sources are required in report preparation. The Task Force will consider information from various sources, including reports and petitions, in preparing annual reports on Internet-related trade restrictions by foreign governments. The report and action plan will be published in the Federal Register, excluding certain information transmitted to Congress. SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative will initiate investigations and potential sanctions within 30 days of each annual report and action plan submission, targeting foreign government acts, policies, or practices that restrict the sale of products in the US. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will conduct reviews and investigations. SEC. 7. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. Antitrust laws include the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress assessing existing trade agreements related to Internet trade, technology standards, Internet security, and information flow. Recommendations for modifications or new agreements will be made to advance these objectives. The sense of Congress is that future trade agreements should include the objectives identified in paragraph (1). The Task Force will coordinate with various entities for standards-related training and organize training for foreign government officials. It will also establish a process for receiving input from businesses and other interested parties.
